subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Which lexical set is the second vowel of _because_ in?
msgSnippet: ... I know that.  My point was that since the forms with stressed /V/ go back to forms with other checked vowels by way of unstressed /@/ it may be advisable
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
> Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:
>
>> But surely any 'low-content' with a vowel frem the 'checked' group (KIT,
>> DRESS, TRAP, FOOT, STRUT, LOT) can get a de-stressed form with schwa?
>> And surely these words should be spellad as if stressed even when
>> they aren't?
>
> True but not relevant here. No matter how much I stress the words
> "of" and "from" (as in the phrase "of but not from", where they have
> contrastive stress), the vowel remains /V/ and never becomes /A/, which
> means that they belong to STRUT and not LOT for me. Not all words are
> absolutely invariant as to lexical set.

I know that. My point was that since the forms with
stressed /V/ go back to forms with other checked vowels by
way of unstressed /@/ it may be advisable to spell these
words according to the 'historical' pronunciations with
un-destressed vowels, at least as long as these
pronunciations actually survive with some speakers.
You may have noted that I also wrote:

BPJ> Where a problem may arise is when such de-stressed
BPJ> forms get a restressed form with /V/, but as long as
the old
BPJ> pre-destressing form also remain in use we should spell
BPJ> according to that.


>> both _him_ and _them_ can become /Vm/ when fully unstressed,
>
> The /@m/ pronunciation of the latter is not a reduction but a
> separate lexeme < OE _hem_.

As I hope you suspected I know that. However the form /@m/
*functions* as the reduced form of /DEm/, the reduced /D@m/
while existing being used only in more formal styles for
many speakers of English. But my main point is that we
would prefer to distinguish the reduced forms of //him// and
//hem// in spelling as {Im} and {Em}, notwithstanding that
they arent actually pronounced so. Similarly we should
probably distinguish _on doing_ and _undoing_ as {Qn doIN}
and {VndoIN}, since the differences in stress which helps
distinguishing them in speech cannot easily be reproduced in
writing, OT or QS, otherwise.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
"C'est en vain que nos Josués littéraires crient
à la langue de s'arrêter; les langues ni le soleil
ne s'arrêtent plus. Le jour où elles se *fixent*,
c'est qu'elles meurent." (Victor Hugo)
